abstract.p: Effective extravehicular-activity (EVA) operations depend upon having the proper tools from simple wrenches to smart powered socket drives to powered adjustable foot restraints. The Space Shuttle carries a standard toolkit in the cargo bay for emergencies. Many special tools have been developed for the recent satellite repair missions; i.e., Solar Max, Westar/Palapa, and Leasat. Many more are being developed to maintain the Hubble Space Telescope on orbit for 15 years. The EVA tools developed and used in space to date are summarized and some of the new tools now in development are described herein. Finally, the requirements are given for several additional tools which may be needed in the future.

ref.mixed-citation: C. E. Whitsett, Manuel Rodriguez, and Leslie J. Rogers, "Recent Shuttle EVA Operations and Experience," SAE Technical Paper 851328, Fifteenth Intersociety Conference on Environmental Systems, San Francisco, CA, July 15-17, 1985.
"EVA Catalog of Tools and Equipment," JSC-20466, NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, 1985.

"Space Transportation System EVA Description and Design Criteria," JSC-10615, Rev. A, NASA Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center, Houston, TX, 1983. Note: This document is being updated and will be reissued as "NSTS 07700, Vol. XIV, App. 7, System Description and Design Requirements for Extravehicular Activities."
"Hubble Space Telescope EVA Tool PDR/CDR Data Package," Dec. 1986. Copies may be obtained from the author.
